channel.title: Calculating loadaverage
channel.description:
I've read online that you take your load average and divide by the number of processors or cores
example: Load Averages: 0.49 0.55 0.54
2 cores: 0.245 00.275 0.27
but what do you do about threads?
do you ignore threads when calculating?
or do you do
loadaverage /= (cores * threads)

item.title: Calculating loadaverage
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

most modern cores can execute threads in parallel

Read full topic

item.title: Calculating loadaverage
item.dc:creator: @silabsoft RuneAgent
item.description:
@silabsoft wrote:

That’s kind of the impression i’m getting as well.

Read full topic

item.title: Calculating loadaverage
item.dc:creator: @Lin Lin
item.description:
@Lin wrote:

I don’t claim to be correct, but I’m pretty sure multiple threads on a single core/processor, for example, don’t actually run concurrently. The processor just switches which thread is being processed but can’t process two at the same. Since the actual workload the processor experiences (provided you ignore any expenses required by switching threads) doesn’t change if you had 1 thread vs 2+ threads, you probably ignore them.

Read full topic
